column2: Act of a child under seven years of age
column3: Sophie (6 years old): In an unintentional act, Sophie spills paint on a neighbor's property while playing, as she is exempt from legal consequences due to being under seven years of age.

column2: Act of a child under seven years of age
column3: James (5 years old): Accidentally breaks a neighbor's window with a ball while playing, demonstrating an act that falls under the exemption for children under seven in legal liability.

column2: Act of a child under seven years of age
column3: Emma (4 years old): Unintentionally damages a neighbor's garden while playing, engaging in an act exempt from legal consequences due to her age.

column2: Act of a child under seven years of age
column3: In a suburban neighborhood, during a community picnic, Sarah's toddler, Emma, innocently wandered away from the designated play area. Unaware of the consequences, Emma, who is under seven years of age, picked up a neighbor's phone from a picnic blanket, mistaking it for a toy. In her playful curiosity, Emma accidentally dropped the phone, causing it to break. The neighbor, understanding the situation, recognized that Emma was too young to comprehend the value of the device and approached Sarah with understanding rather than seeking any form of compensation.

column2: Act of a child under seven years of age
column3: During a family gathering, Mark's five-year-old son, Jake, unknowingly entered a neighbor's backyard where a small gardening event was taking place. In his exploration, Jake, fascinated by the colorful flowers, picked a few blossoms and unintentionally damaged a potted plant. The neighbor, recognizing Jake's age and innocence, approached Mark with understanding, and they resolved the situation amicably without pursuing any compensation for the minor damage.

column2: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding
column3: Mark (Age 9): Accidentally damages a neighbor's bicycle while playing, demonstrating an act due to immature understanding.

column2: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding
column3: Being under twelve, damages school property unintentionally, showcasing an act due to immature understanding.

column2: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding
column3: Aged seven, unintentionally spills paint on a public bench, engaging in an act exempt from full legal consequences.

column2: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding
column3: At a local bookstore, Emily, an eight-year-old with an immature understanding, unintentionally damaged a display of books while exploring the aisles. Emily, fascinated by a book on a high shelf, attempted to reach for it, accidentally knocking over several neighboring books in the process.

column2: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding
column3: Imagine an 11-year-old child, aware of the concept of ownership but not fully grasping the consequences of actions, takes a neighbor's bicycle for a joyride without asking for permission. Due to the child's immature understanding, the act is done without a clear comprehension of the potential harm or violation involved. In such a case, the legal system might consider the child's age and level of understanding, recognizing that the child's actions stem from an immature understanding rather than malicious intent.

column2: a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
column3: Due to a temporary episode of severe mental illness, David, at the time, is incapable of understanding the nature of his actions when engaging in an unintended act.

column2: a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
column3: Suffers from a momentary lapse of sanity, causing Sophie to be temporarily incapable of realizing that her actions are wrong or contrary to the law during a specific incident.

column2: a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
column3: Experiences a bout of mental incapacity, rendering James unable to comprehend the nature of his actions or recognize that they are contrary to the law at the time of the event.

column2: a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
column3: Sarah, diagnosed with severe mental illness, enters a shopping mall convinced a common item is magical. She causes panic by waving it, leading to her detention. Her actions highlight the impact of unsound mind on behavior and the need for understanding in society.

column2: a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
column3: Consider a situation where an individual, due to a severe and temporary episode of mental illness, is unable to understand the nature of their actions. During this period, they engage in an activity that would typically be considered an offense, such as breaking a window in a fit of confusion. However, due to the person's unsoundness of mind at that specific time, they lack the capacity to comprehend the nature of their act or recognize that it is wrong or against the law. In such a case, the legal system may recognize that the individual is not criminally responsible for their actions.

column2: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will
column3: Mark unknowingly consumes a drink spiked with a potent substance, causing him to be incapable of judgment due to intoxication against his will during a social gathering.

column2: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will
column3: Sophie attends a party where someone intentionally slips a substance into her beverage, rendering her incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication against her will.

column2: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will
column3: At a bar, James unintentionally consumes a drink with a substance added without his knowledge, leading to his incapacity of judgment due to intoxication against his will.

column2: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will
column3: Mark, against his will, ingests a spiked drink at a party. As a result, he becomes heavily intoxicated and loses the ability to make reasoned judgments. In this vulnerable state, he unwittingly engages in disruptive behavior, emphasizing the importance of consent and responsible conduct in social settings.

column2: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will
column3: John attends a party where someone slips a powerful drug into his drink without his knowledge. As a result, John becomes severely intoxicated and incapable of judgment. Any actions he takes during this state may be considered exempt from legal consequences due to his involuntary intoxication.

column2: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated
column3: Intoxicated at a party, David, without the required intent or knowledge, accidentally damages property, committing an offense due to his impaired state.

column2: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated
column3: While under the influence, Sophie unintentionally discloses confidential information at work, committing an offense that requires a specific intent or knowledge.

column2: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated
column3: Emma, lacking the required intent or knowledge, inadvertently trespasses onto private property, committing an offense during her intoxicated state.

column2: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated
column3: Jake, heavily intoxicated, attends a party. In his impaired state, he mistakenly believes his friend's car is his own and decides to take it for a joyride. Unaware of the consequences, he commits a crime of theft, emphasizing the legal challenge of determining intent or knowledge when offenses are committed under the influence of alcohol.

column2: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated
column3: Sarah, under the influence of alcohol she consumed unknowingly, unintentionally damages valuable property while attempting to find her way home. Her actions, though constituting an offense that typically requires intent or knowledge, may be considered differently due to her state of intoxication.

column2: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt done by consent
column3: Mark, with consent, participates in a combat sport where he unintentionally causes minor injuries to his opponent, as the act was neither intended nor known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt.

column2: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt done by consent
column3: Nathan, with consent, participates in a physical training session where he unintentionally causes minor injuries to a training partner, as the act was not intended and not known to be likely to cause severe harm.

column2: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt done by consent
column3: While engaging in a recreational activity, James, with consent, accidentally inflicts minor injuries on a friend, as the act was neither intended nor known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt.

column2: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt done by consent
column3: Consider a scenario where two individuals engage in a contact sport, such as boxing, and agree to participate in a match. Despite the physical nature of the activity, the blows exchanged are not intended to cause death or grievous hurt. Both participants consent to the sport, understanding the risks involved, and any resulting injuries are considered within the scope of their agreed-upon activ

column2: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt done by consent
column3: Sarah and Mark, engage in a friendly game of paintball. Sarah consents to the game, understanding the risks. In the heat of the moment, Mark accidentally fires a paintball from close range, causing a minor injury to Sarah.

column2: Act not intended to cause death done by consent in good faith for person's benefit
column3: David, with consent and in good faith, performs a medical procedure not intended to cause death but for the person's benefit, aiming to improve their overall health.

column2: Act not intended to cause death done by consent in good faith for person's benefit
column3: In a therapeutic setting, Sophie administers a treatment with the person's consent and in good faith, not intending to cause death but aiming to provide a beneficial outcome for their well-being.

column2: Act not intended to cause death done by consent in good faith for person's benefit
column3: In a rehabilitation session, Emma, with the person's consent and in good faith, undertakes an action not meant to cause death but intended for the individual's benefit and recovery

column2: Act not intended to cause death done by consent in good faith for person's benefit
column3: Anna, a passerby, finds Mark unconscious on the sidewalk. Thinking quickly, she decides to perform CPR in an attempt to revive him. Despite Anna's good intentions, Mark unfortunately does not recover. Anna's act, not intended to cause death but done in good faith for Mark's benefit, aligns with legal principles exempting such actions from liability.

column2: Act not intended to cause death done by consent in good faith for person's benefit
column3: An example of an act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for a person's benefit, could be a medical surgery. When a person consents to a surgical procedure for their well-being, the surgeon may perform actions that, while not intended to cause death, are necessary for the person's health improvement. The consent and good faith involved distinguish it from an unlawful act.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian
column3: Mark, as the legal guardian, consents to a necessary medical procedure for the benefit of his child, performed in good faith to improve the child's health.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian
column3: Sophie, acting as the guardian of an insane person, consents to a therapeutic intervention performed in good faith, seeking to enhance the well-being of the individual.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian
column3: Nathan, acting as the guardian, approves a necessary and beneficial surgical procedure for his child, done in good faith to improve the child's health and well-being.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian
column3: Sarah, a caregiver, notices a child, Emily, choking on a small object. Recognizing the immediate danger, Sarah performs the Heimlich maneuver to dislodge the object and save Emily. Sarah's action, done in good faith for the benefit of the child and with the consent of her guardian, aligns with legal principles that exempt such acts from liability, even if unintended consequences occur.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian
column3: A doctor, with the consent of a parent or guardian, administers a necessary and beneficial medical treatment to a child suffering from a serious illness. The act is done in good faith for the benefit of the child's health and well-being, and with the consent of the responsible guardian, aligning with the legal provision specified.

column2: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception
column3: David, under the fear of losing his job, reluctantly gives consent to a business decision, the consent being known to be given under the influence of fear.

column2: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception
column3: Emma, under the misconception of imminent danger, hastily consents to a medical procedure, the consent known to be given under the influence of a false belief.

column2: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception
column3: James, fearing social isolation, reluctantly agrees to participate in an event, the consent known to be given under the influence of fear and not genuine willingness.

column2: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception
column3: Emma, a recent graduate desperate for employment, applies for a job at a small company. The employer, Mark, takes advantage of Emma's eagerness and uses coercion to secure her consent to an unfavorable employment contract.

column2: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception
column3: Suppose Sarah, under the fear of losing her job, consents to a coworker's romantic advances believing it would secure her employment. The consent is given under the influence of fear and misconception, as the coworker has led her to believe that her job security depends on the romantic relationship.

column2: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused
column3: Aarav, without causing harm, engages in peaceful protests which, although creating disruption, are not offenses independently of the harm caused.

column2: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused
column3: Ishaan, while expressing dissent through writings, does not commit an offense independently of the harm caused, as his actions fall within the realm of free speech and expression.

column2: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused
column3: Aisha, organizing a peaceful assembly to address grievances, commits no offense independently of harm caused, as the gathering is within the legal boundaries.

column2: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused
column3: John and Sarah, two acquaintances facing financial difficulties, conspire to commit theft from a local electronics store. Their plan is to steal high-value electronic devices and sell them to alleviate their financial troubles.

column2: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused
column3: Consider a situation where Mark unlawfully enters a restricted government facility, violating security protocols. Even if Mark causes no harm or damage during the entry, the act of trespassing itself is an offense independently of any harm caused. The exclusion mentioned refers to cases where an act is considered an offense regardless of whether harm is inflicted.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
column3: Anika, a medical professional, administers emergency treatment to an unconscious person without their consent, acting in good faith for the benefit of the individual's health.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
column3: Rohan, a first responder, performs life-saving procedures on an accident victim without their consent, acting in good faith to ensure the person's well-being.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
column3: Sneha, a caregiver, makes a critical decision on behalf of an incapacitated person's medical care without their consent, acting in good faith for the individual's benefit.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
column3: Jane, a trained medical professional, comes across a severely injured person, Mark, who has been involved in a car accident. Mark is unconscious, and there are no immediate bystanders around. In good faith and believing it is in Mark's best interest, Jane administers emergency medical treatment without obtaining explicit consent.

column2: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
column3: An emergency medical professional, witnessing a person collapse in a public place and unable to obtain explicit consent, performs life-saving CPR in good faith for the benefit of the unconscious individual. Despite the lack of consent, the action is done with the sincere belief that it is in the person's best interest and is exempt from legal consequences under certain circumstances.

column2: Communication made in good faith
column3: Amit, a concerned friend, shares information about a potential health risk with another friend in good faith, aiming to ensure their well-being and safety.

column2: Communication made in good faith
column3: Radhika, a colleague, communicates honest feedback to her team member in good faith, intending to contribute to their professional growth and development.

column2: Communication made in good faith
column3: Raj, a family member, provides constructive advice to his sibling in good faith, expressing genuine concern for their personal and academic success.

column2: Communication made in good faith
column3: Sarah, a teacher at a local elementary school, becomes concerned about the well-being of one of her students, Jake. Over the course of several weeks, she observes changes in Jake's behavior and physical appearance that raise suspicions of possible child abuse at home. In good faith, Sarah decides to report her concerns to the appropriate child protection authorities.

column2: Communication made in good faith
column3: A person, genuinely concerned for a friend's well-being, communicates their worries about the friend's health to a healthcare professional. The communication is made in good faith, without any malicious intent or false information, with the sincere aim of seeking help for the friend's benefit.

column2: Act to which a person is compelled by threats
column3: Neha, under threat of harm to her family, is compelled to share confidential information at her workplace against her will.

column2: Act to which a person is compelled by threats
column3: Rajat, facing threats of physical harm, is compelled to participate in an unauthorized activity that goes against his principles and values.

column2: Act to which a person is compelled by threats
column3: Kavita, threatened with the release of sensitive personal information, is compelled to carry out actions contrary to her wishes and beliefs.

column2: Act to which a person is compelled by threats
column3: In the close-knit community of Harmony Haven, a troubling situation unfolded when an individual, Sarah, found herself compelled to engage in an undesirable act due to threats made by a coercive party named Alex. Fearing harm and coercion, Sarah reluctantly complied with the demands under duress. The matter was reported to local authorities, who recognized the gravity of the situation and intervened promptly. In subsequent legal proceedings, the court acknowledged the circumstances of the act being compelled by threats and aimed to address the coercion while emphasizing Harmony Haven's commitment to ensuring the safety and well-being of its residents by discouraging and penalizing such coercive behaviors.

column2: Act to which a person is compelled by threats
column3: John, under threat of physical harm to himself and his family, is compelled to transfer money from his bank account to the perpetrator's account. The act of transferring money is done solely due to the threats made against John and his family, illustrating a situation where a person is compelled to act under duress.

column2: Act causing slight harm
column3: Rahul accidentally bumps into a colleague, causing a slight bruise, during a crowded office event.

column2: Act causing slight harm
column3: Shreya, while playing a sport, inadvertently causes a minor injury to a friend by colliding during the game.

column2: Act causing slight harm
column3: Vivek, in a rush, unintentionally steps on someone's foot, causing slight discomfort during a busy market day.

column2: Act causing slight harm
column3: In the peaceful town of Serenityville, a minor incident occurred when two neighbors, Alex and Jamie, were involved in a brief altercation that resulted in slight harm. The situation was promptly reported to local authorities, who intervened to assess the circumstances. Recognizing the relatively minor nature of the incident, the legal proceedings aimed at resolving the matter amicably. The town emphasized its commitment to maintaining a tranquil environment and encouraging peaceful resolutions in cases involving minor harm, ensuring that community members coexist harmoniously.

column2: Act causing slight harm
column3: Sarah accidentally bumps into Mark while rushing through a crowded space, causing him to spill a bit of his coffee. The act, though unintentional, results in slight harm to Mark's clothing and a minor inconvenience.

column2: Things done in private defence
column3: Amit, faced with an imminent physical threat, uses necessary force to protect himself from an aggressive assailant in a dark alley.

column2: Things done in private defence
column3: Priya, encountering an intruder in her home, acts in self-defense by using reasonable force to prevent potential harm to herself and her family.

column2: Things done in private defence
column3: Neha, facing an attempted robbery, exercises her right to private defense by using necessary force to protect her belongings and personal safety.

column2: Things done in private defence
column3: In the suburban community of Greenwood Hills, Emily found herself in a perilous situation during a late-night encounter with a potential assailant. Fearing for her safety, Emily took actions in self-defense, later revealed to be in response to an imminent threat. Recognizing the circumstances, local authorities concluded that Emily's actions were done in private defense. The legal proceedings acknowledged the right of individuals to protect themselves from harm, emphasizing Greenwood Hills' commitment to ensuring the safety and well-being of its residents within the bounds of the law.

column2: Things done in private defence
column3: Consider a situation where Tom is walking alone at night, and an unknown person suddenly approaches him aggressively. In self-defense, Tom raises his hands to ward off the potential attacker, signaling his readiness to protect himself if necessary. These defensive actions fall within the scope of private defense, as Tom is responding to a perceived threat to his safety.

column2: Right of private defence of the body and of property
column3: Kiran, fearing an imminent physical assault, exercises the right of private defense to protect himself by using necessary force against an aggressor.

column2: Right of private defence of the body and of property
column3: Smita, facing a break-in at her home, invokes the right of private defense to safeguard her property, using reasonable force to repel the intruder.

column2: Right of private defence of the body and of property
column3: Rajat, confronted by a group attempting to vandalize his car, employs the right of private defense to prevent damage to his property by using necessary force.

column2: Right of private defence of the body and of property
column3: Alex, a shopkeeper, notices a person attempting to steal merchandise from his store. Recognizing the threat to his property, Alex approaches the individual and requests them to stop. However, the person becomes aggressive and tries to physically harm Alex. In response to the imminent danger, Alex uses necessary force to defend himself and prevent the theft, invoking his right of private defense of both his body and property under IPC 97.

column2: Right of private defence of the body and of property
column3: Imagine Kate, walking in a secluded area, encounters an individual who attempts to physically assault her. In exercising her right of private defense of the body, Kate uses reasonable force to protect herself, deterring the assailant and ensuring her safety. This example illustrates the right of private defense concerning personal safety.

column2: Right of private defence against the act of a person of unsound mind, etc.
column3: Anita, facing an aggressive person of unsound mind attempting to cause harm, exercises the right of private defense to protect herself by using necessary force.

column2: Right of private defence against the act of a person of unsound mind, etc.
column3: Vikrant, encountering an individual with a history of violent behavior due to mental illness, asserts the right of private defense to prevent potential harm by using reasonable force.

column2: Right of private defence against the act of a person of unsound mind, etc.
column3: Swati, in a situation where a person of unsound mind poses a threat, invokes the right of private defense to safeguard her well-being by using necessary force against the aggressor.

column2: Right of private defence against the act of a person of unsound mind, etc.
column3: John, a teacher at a special needs school, observes one of the students, Mark, exhibiting aggressive behavior due to his unsound mental state. Mark suddenly becomes physically violent, posing a threat to other students in the classroom. In order to protect the other students and himself, John uses reasonable force to restrain Mark until additional help arrives.

column2: Right of private defence against the act of a person of unsound mind, etc.
column3: Consider a scenario where Mary, who is known to have occasional violent episodes due to a mental health condition, starts behaving aggressively and poses a threat to those around her. In response to her immediate threat, Tom, who is present at the scene, uses reasonable force to restrain Mary until professional help arrives. Here, Tom is exercising the right of private defense against the act of a person with an unsound mind to protect himself and others from potential harm.

column2: Acts against which there is no right of private defence
column3: Aditya, witnessing a verbal insult, cannot claim the right of private defense as mere offensive language does not warrant physical retaliation.

column2: Acts against which there is no right of private defence
column3: Priya, facing property damage caused by negligence, does not have the right of private defense as the act is not intentional aggression that justifies physical force.

column2: Acts against which there is no right of private defence
column3: Anjali, encountering a harmless prank, cannot assert the right of private defense as the act is playful and does not pose a genuine threat.

column2: Acts against which there is no right of private defence
column3: Engaging in actions where there is no right of private defense, an individual intentionally trespassed onto a neighbor's property to retrieve a misplaced item. The neighbor, though alarmed by the intrusion, refrained from any form of retaliation, understanding that the act did not pose an imminent threat to life or property. In such situations where the right of private defense is not applicable, the aggrieved party chose to address the issue through legal channels rather than resorting to self-defense measures.

column2: Acts against which there is no right of private defence
column3: In a dispute over a minor property boundary issue, one party resorted to verbal abuse and harassment. The targeted individual, recognizing the absence of an imminent threat to physical well-being or property, refrained from retaliatory actions. In this scenario where the situation did not warrant the right of private defense, the affected party opted to address the matter through legal means rather than resorting to any form of counter-aggression.

column2: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death
column3: Neha, encountering a violent home invasion where her life is in imminent danger, asserts the right of private defense, using necessary force, including causing death, to safeguard her well-being.

column2: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death
column3: Kavita, facing a life-threatening assault, exercises the right of private defense, using necessary force, including causing death, to defend herself from an imminent danger.

column2: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death
column3: Vikram, confronting a deadly attack with potential fatal consequences, asserts the right of private defense, using necessary force, including causing death, to ensure his survival in a life-threatening situation.

column2: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death
column3: Tom, in a fit of rage, engages in a physical altercation with his neighbor, Alex. During the fight, Tom forcefully shoves Alex, causing him to fall and hit his head on a hard surface. Alex sustains severe injuries and later succumbs to the head trauma. In this scenario, Tom's act of forcefully shoving Alex, resulting in fatal injuries, may amount to culpable homicide, as it involves the intentional use of force leading to unintended but foreseeable lethal consequences.

column2: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death
column3: Sarah, walking alone at night, is suddenly confronted by an armed assailant who threatens her life. In a desperate act of self-defense, Sarah manages to gain control of the assailant's weapon and, fearing for her own life, uses it to neutralize the imminent threat, causing the assailant's death.

column3: When Dax faced an imminent physical assault, he skillfully incapacitated his attacker without resorting to lethal force,

Tom, a homeowner, catches a burglar attempting to break into his residence late at night. Tom, in a bid to protect himself and his property, issues warnings to the intruder. Despite the warnings, the intruder brandishes a weapon, leaving Tom with no choice but to use a firearm in self-defense. The incident tragically results in the intruder's death, highlighting the extreme circumstances under which the right of private defense of property extends to causing death

Consider a situation where Sarah, a homeowner, hears loud noises in the middle of the night. Upon investigation, she discovers an intruder attempting to break into her house. Fearing for her life and recognizing the offense as house-breaking by night, Sarah exercises her right of private defense. In the process, she takes actions that unintentionally result in harm to the intruder, falling within the circumstances outlined where the right of private defense is justified.

Kiran, a homeowner, confronted a group of armed intruders attempting a house-breaking by night. Fearing for his life and the safety of his family, Kiran resorted to the voluntary causing of harm to thwart the intrusion

Ramesh, while walking through a dimly lit alley, was suddenly accosted by Jayesh and Devang, who attempted to rob him at knifepoint. Faced with an immediate threat of robbery, Ramesh took decisive action to protect himself,
Suresh, in a remote location, found himself surrounded by a group engaged in mischief by fire, threatening to set fire to a building where he and others were present.

column2: If the offence, the committing of which, or the attempting to commit which occasions the exercise of the right of private defence, be theft, mischief, or criminal trespass, not of any of the descriptions enumerated in the last preceding section, that right does not extend to the voluntary causing of death, but does extend, subject to the restrictions mentioned in section 99, to the voluntary causing to the wrong-doer of any harm other than death.
column3: Alex, a homeowner, spots intruders attempting to vandalize his car parked in the driveway. Worried about the potential harm and damage, Alex confronts the vandals and uses a loud alarm to scare them away. In the process, one of the vandals falls and sustains minor injuries, illustrating the right of private defense of property extending to causing harm other than death.

column2: If the offence, the committing of which, or the attempting to commit which occasions the exercise of the right of private defence, be theft, mischief, or criminal trespass, not of any of the descriptions enumerated in the last preceding section, that right does not extend to the voluntary causing of death, but does extend, subject to the restrictions mentioned in section 99, to the voluntary causing to the wrong-doer of any harm other than death.
column3: Imagine Mary catching someone attempting to steal her bicycle in the backyard. In response, she decides to exercise her right of private defense to protect her property. However, as the offense is theft and not one of the specific offenses mentioned in the previous section, Mary's right does not extend to causing the thief's death. She may, however, use reasonable force to prevent the theft or cause harm other than death to the wrongdoer, within the limits specified by Section 99.

column2: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk.
column3: Lucy is walking through a crowded market when she witnesses an assailant attacking an innocent passerby with a knife. Recognizing the immediate danger and the risk of harm to the innocent person, Lucy intervenes to protect them. In self-defense and with the aim of preventing harm to the victim, Lucy uses force to disarm the assailant. In this scenario, Lucy is invoking her right of private defense against a deadly assault with the added consideration of preventing harm to an innocent p

column2: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk.
column3: Jay found himself under a sudden, life-threatening assault by Krish, who was armed and had a history of violent behavior. To defend himself, Jay realized that the only available escape route was through a crowded market where innocent bystanders were at risk.

column2: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk.
column3: Prince, while returning home, was confronted by an armed assailant, Krish, who posed a severe threat to his life. Unarmed and realizing he couldn't effectively defend himself without endangering nearby pedestrians, Prince decided to flee towards a busy street.

column2: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk.
column3: Jay found himself in a life-threatening situation as Krish, armed with a deadly weapon, attacked him. Recognizing that retaliating directly would pose an imminent risk to nearby innocent persons, Jay strategically retreated to a more open area, choosing to face Krish where the risk to others was minimized.

column2: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk.
column3: Suppose Tom is in a crowded public place when he is suddenly attacked by an armed assailant with a deadly weapon, creating a reasonable apprehension of death. Tom, in the midst of the crowded area, recognizes that any attempt to evade the attack might endanger innocent bystanders. In this scenario, Tom's right of private defense extends to the reasonable running of the risk of harm to himself in order to protect others in the vicinity from potential harm caused by the assailant.

column2: Public servant disobeying law with intent to cause injury to any person
column3: Officer Smith, a police officer entrusted with upholding the law, harbors personal animosity towards a local activist, Alex, who has been vocal about police misconduct. In an attempt to retaliate against Alex, Officer Smith decides to intentionally disobey the law.

column2: Public servant disobeying law with intent to cause injury to any person
column3: Lisa, a municipal official responsible for licensing and permits, holds a personal grudge against a local business owner, Jake, who refused to comply with her demands for a bribe. Seeking revenge, Lisa decides to intentionally misuse her authority.

column2: Public servant framing an incorrect document with intent to cause injury
column3: Emily, a public servant working in the human resources department of a government agency, holds a personal grudge against one of her colleagues, Alex. Seeking revenge for a perceived slight, Emily decides to frame an incorrect document to cause injury to Alex.

column2: Public servant framing an incorrect document with intent to cause injury
column3: Jack, a public prosecutor, holds a personal vendetta against a prominent business owner, Sarah, who had successfully defended herself against charges brought by Jack in a previous case. Seeking revenge, Jack decides to engage in unethical practices.

column2: Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade
column3: Emily works as a high-ranking government official in the Department of Finance. In her position, she has access to confidential information about upcoming economic policies and financial decisions that can significantly impact the stock market.

column2: Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade
column3: Mark, a government procurement officer, is responsible for awarding contracts to private companies bidding for government projects. Mark discovers that a major infrastructure project is about to be awarded to a specific company, and this information is not yet public.

column2: Public servant unlawfully buying or bidding for property
column3: Sarah, a public official working in a government department responsible for acquiring land for public projects, discovers that a piece of land with significant development potential is about to be put up for sale.

column2: Public servant unlawfully buying or bidding for property
column3: John, a public official working in the city's surplus property division, is responsible for managing the auction of government-owned properties. He learns about an upcoming auction for a prime piece of real estate that has garnered significant interest from potential buyers.

column2: Personating a public servant
column3: Alex, an individual with a background in construction, decides to exploit his knowledge to deceive and extort money from local businesses. He fabricates an official-looking uniform and identification badge, resembling those worn by building inspectors.

column2: Personating a public servant
column3: Lisa, motivated by a desire for authority and control, decides to impersonate a police officer to exploit unsuspecting individuals.

column2: Wearing garb or carrying token used by public servant with fraudulent intent.—Whoever, not belonging to a certain class of public servants, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by that class of public servants, with the intention that it may be believed, or with the knowledge that it is likely to be believed, that he belongs to that class of public servants,
column3: Suppose John, not being a police officer, wears a police uniform and carries a fake police badge with the intention of gaining unauthorized access to restricted areas. His fraudulent intent is to deceive others into believing that he belongs to the police force. This example aligns with the described offense of wearing garb or carrying a token used by public servants with fraudulent intent.

column2: Wearing garb or carrying token used by public servant with fraudulent intent.—Whoever, not belonging to a certain class of public servants, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by that class of public servants, with the intention that it may be believed, or with the knowledge that it is likely to be believed, that he belongs to that class of public servants,
column3: Imagine Sarah, not being a firefighter, dresses in a firefighter's uniform and carries a fake fire department identification card. She enters a restricted area during an emergency, intending to take advantage of the situation and gain unauthorized access. In this scenario, Sarah's actions align with the offense of wearing garb or carrying a token used by public servants with fraudulent intent.

column2: Whoever absconds in order to avoid being served with a summons, notice or order proceeding from any public servant legally competent, as such public servant, to issue such summons, notice or order
column3: Suppose John, upon learning that he is about to be served with a court summons related to a legal matter, deliberately leaves town and goes into hiding to avoid being served. In this case, John's act of absconding is motivated by the desire to evade the legal process initiated by a public servant authorized to issue the summon

column2: Whoever absconds in order to avoid being served with a summons, notice or order proceeding from any public servant legally competent, as such public servant, to issue such summons, notice or order
column3: Imagine Sarah, aware that a public servant is set to serve her with an eviction notice due to non-payment of rent, quickly leaves her residence and stays with friends to avoid receiving the legal notice. Sarah's act of absconding is driven by the intention to evade the consequences of the notice issued by a competent public servant.

column2: If someone intentionally hinders the delivery of a summons, notice, order, or proclamation from a public servant
column3: Consider a situation where Alex, aware that a public servant is scheduled to deliver a legal notice to his home, locks the gate, preventing the process server from entering the property. Alex's intentional hindrance of the delivery obstructs the public servant's attempt to serve the notice in a timely manner

column2: If someone intentionally hinders the delivery of a summons, notice, order, or proclamation from a public servant
column3: Imagine Sarah, anticipating the delivery of a court summons related to a legal dispute, instructs her neighbor to refuse entry to anyone attempting to serve her with legal documents. By intentionally interfering with the delivery process, Sarah hinders the public servant's efforts to serve the summons.

column2: If someone is legally required to appear at a certain place and time in response to a summons, notice, order, or proclamation from a public servant but intentionally fails to attend or leaves before the allowed time
column3: Suppose John receives a summons to appear as a witness in court on a specific date and time. However, intentionally choosing not to attend, John skips the court hearing and leaves the jurisdiction before the scheduled time. This example illustrates the intentional failure to appear at the required place and time as directed by the public servant's summons.

column2: If someone is legally required to appear at a certain place and time in response to a summons, notice, order, or proclamation from a public servant but intentionally fails to attend or leaves before the allowed time
column3: Consider the scenario where Alex, served with an official order to attend a community meeting about local zoning changes, intentionally fails to appear at the designated time and place. Instead, Alex leaves the area before the scheduled meeting, disregarding the requirement set by the public servant's order.

column2: If someone is legally required to show or hand over a document to a public servant but intentionally fails to do so
column3: Suppose Mark is legally obligated to provide his financial records in response to a tax audit notice from a government tax official. However, intentionally refusing to comply, Mark fails to hand over the requested documents within the specified timeframe, thereby violating the obligation to furnish the required information to the public servant.

column2: If someone is legally required to show or hand over a document to a public servant but intentionally fails to do so
column3: Imagine Sarah, in a business inspection, is requested by a government health inspector to provide documentation regarding the safety protocols in her restaurant. However, intentionally failing to do so, Sarah refuses to show the required documents to the public servant, disregarding the legal obligation to provide necessary information during the inspection.

column2: If someone is legally obligated to provide notice or information to a public servant but intentionally fails to do so
column3: Suppose John is required by law to notify a government environmental agency about certain emissions from his factory. Intentionally failing to fulfill this obligation, John neglects to provide the necessary information to the relevant public servant, thereby violating the legal requirement.

column2: If someone is legally obligated to provide notice or information to a public servant but intentionally fails to do so
column3: Consider a scenario where Sarah, as a business owner, is legally obligated to inform the local health department about a recent food safety issue in her restaurant. However, intentionally choosing not to fulfill this obligation, Sarah fails to provide the necessary notice or information to the public servant responsible for overseeing health and safety standards.

column2: If someone is legally required to provide information to a public servant but knowingly gives false information
column3: Suppose Alex, during a government audit, is required by law to provide accurate financial information about his business. However, knowingly giving false information, Alex provides misleading figures to the tax official, violating the legal obligation to provide truthful and accurate details to the public servant.

column2: If someone is legally required to provide information to a public servant but knowingly gives false information
column3: Consider a scenario where Sarah, as a witness in a court proceeding, is legally obligated to provide truthful testimony. However, knowingly giving false information on the witness stand, Sarah provides misleading statements that misrepresent the facts of the case, contravening the legal obligation to offer accurate information to the public servant overseeing the legal proceedings.

column2: If someone refuses to take an oath or affirm to tell the truth when legally asked to do so by a public servant
column3: Suppose John is called as a witness in a court case, and the judge asks him to take an oath or affirm to tell the truth before testifying. However, John refuses to take the oath or affirm, demonstrating non-compliance with the legal requirement set by the public servant overseeing the court proceedings.

column2: If someone refuses to take an oath or affirm to tell the truth when legally asked to do so by a public servant
column3: Consider a scenario where Sarah is called to testify during a government inquiry, and the investigating officer asks her to take an oath or affirm to provide truthful information. Refusing to take the oath or affirm, Sarah declines to commit to telling the truth, thereby failing to comply with the legal requirement when questioned by the public servant.

column2: If someone who is required by law to tell the truth to a public servant refuses to answer their questions
column3: Suppose Alex, during a police investigation, is legally obligated to provide truthful information. However, when questioned by the police officer, Alex refuses to answer any questions, invoking his right to remain silent. In this example, Alex's refusal to answer questions demonstrates non-compliance with the legal obligation to truthfully respond to the public servant's inquiries.

column2: If someone who is required by law to tell the truth to a public servant refuses to answer their questions
column3: Consider a scenario where Sarah, a witness in a government inquiry, is required by law to provide accurate information. However, when asked specific questions by the inquiry officer, Sarah refuses to answer, citing concerns about self-incrimination. In this instance, Sarah's refusal to respond illustrates a failure to comply with the legal obligation to truthfully answer questions posed by the public servant conducting the inquiry.

column2: Whoever refuses to sign any statement made by him, when required to sign that statement by a public servant legally competent to require that he shall sign that statement
column3: Imagine John, a witness in a police investigation, provides a statement detailing an incident. The investigating officer, legally competent to require signatures on statements, asks John to sign the document for authentication. However, John refuses to sign the statement, expressing reservations about potential consequences. This refusal to sign exemplifies a situation where an individual declines to comply with the request of a public servant to sign a statement.

column2: Whoever refuses to sign any statement made by him, when required to sign that statement by a public servant legally competent to require that he shall sign that statement
column3: Consider a situation where Sarah, a witness in a legal proceeding, provides a detailed account of an incident to a police officer. The officer, legally competent to authenticate statements, requests Sarah to sign the document to confirm its accuracy. However, Sarah, for personal reasons or concerns, refuses to sign the statement, demonstrating a refusal to comply with the request of a public servant legally competent to require her signature.

column2: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or affirmation to state the truth on any subject to any public servant or other person authorized by law to administer such oath or affirmation, makes, to such public servant or other person as aforesaid, touching that subject, any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true
column3: Suppose Alex, while under oath during a court trial, is asked about his financial assets in a divorce proceeding. Despite being legally bound by the oath to tell the truth, Alex provides false information about his income and assets, intentionally misleading the court. This example illustrates a situation where an individual, bound by an oath to state the truth, knowingly provides false information to a public servant or authorized person.

column2: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or affirmation to state the truth on any subject to any public servant or other person authorized by law to administer such oath or affirmation, makes, to such public servant or other person as aforesaid, touching that subject, any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true
column3: Imagine Sarah, sworn in as a witness during a government inquiry into a financial scandal, is asked about her involvement in certain transactions. Despite being legally bound by the oath to state the truth, Sarah intentionally provides false information about her role, knowing that the information is untrue. This example demonstrates a violation of the legal obligation to provide truthful statements when under oath to a public servant or authorized person

column2: someone knowingly gives false information to a public servant with the intention of causing them to do something they shouldn't or use their power to harm someone
column3: Suppose John, with malicious intent, provides false information to a police officer, claiming that his neighbor, Sarah, is involved in illegal activities. John knows that this information is false, but he intentionally misleads the officer with the aim of causing harm to Sarah or taking advantage of the officer's authority to settle a personal dispute. This example illustrates the act of knowingly providing false information to a public servant with the intention of causing them to misuse their power to the detriment of someone else

column2: someone knowingly gives false information to a public servant with the intention of causing them to do something they shouldn't or use their power to harm someone
column3: Emily, with malicious intent, provides false information to a government official, Officer Rodriguez, claiming that her coworker, Javier, is involved in fraudulent activities. Emily knows that this information is false, but she intentionally misleads Officer Rodriguez with the aim of causing harm to Javier or taking advantage of the officer's authority to settle a personal dispute. This example illustrates the act of knowingly providing false information to a public servant with the intention of causing them to misuse their power to the detriment of someone else.

column2: someone resists the lawful taking of any property by a public servant, knowing or believing that the person is a public servant
column3: Suppose Sarah, a tax collector, legally arrives at Mark's property to seize assets due to unpaid taxes. Mark, aware that Sarah is a public servant, forcefully resists the lawful attempt to take his property, believing he has the right to prevent the action. In this example, Mark resists the lawful taking of property by a public servant, knowing or believing the person is acting in an official capacity.

column2: someone resists the lawful taking of any property by a public servant, knowing or believing that the person is a public servant
column3: During a legal repossession of a vehicle, Lisa forcefully resists Officer Johnson, a public servant tasked with the repossession, believing she has the right to prevent the lawful taking of her car. In this situation, Lisa resists the action, knowing that Officer Johnson is a public servant carrying out official duties.

column2: someone intentionally obstructs the sale of property that is being offered for sale by a public servant.
column3: Suppose Maria, aware of a court-ordered auction of seized property conducted by a public servant, intentionally organizes a protest and obstructs potential buyers from participating. Her goal is to disrupt the sale and prevent the successful transaction of the property offered for sale by the public servant.

column2: someone intentionally obstructs the sale of property that is being offered for sale by a public servant.
column3: Imagine Michael intentionally blocking access to an estate sale organized by a public servant. Michael, aware of the planned sale, obstructs the entrance, preventing potential buyers from entering and participating in the sale of the property. This example illustrates the intentional obstruction of the sale of property being offered by a public servant

column2: someone purchases or bids for property at a public sale on behalf of a person who is legally not allowed to do so or bids without intending to fulfill the obligations.
column3: Emily Turner, a wealthy heiress barred from direct participation in property auctions due to legal restrictions, enlisted the aid of Michael Lawson in a covert plan to acquire a coveted piece of real estate. Michael, armed with a power of attorney and feigning innocence, attended the public auction as Emily's proxy bidder. Unbeknownst to other attendees, his intentions were far from genuine, and he manipulated the bidding process to secure the property without any intention of fulfilling the associated obligations.

column2: someone purchases or bids for property at a public sale on behalf of a person who is legally not allowed to do so or bids without intending to fulfill the obligations.
column3: Mr. Devious and his unwitting partner, Ms. Duped, tried to buy a property at a public auction for Mr. Restrained, who legally couldn't do it himself. They pretended to be genuine bidders but had no intention of following through with the purchase.

column2: someone intentionally obstructs a public servant from performing their duties.
column3: Officer Smith, a dedicated public servant, was diligently patrolling the streets to ensure the safety of its residents. One day, a mischievous individual named Jake, harboring a grudge against law enforcement, decided to intentionally obstruct Officer Smith from performing his duties. As Officer Smith was responding to a call about a disturbance, Jake purposely blocked the patrol car with his own vehicle, preventing the officer from reaching the scene promptly.

column2: someone intentionally obstructs a public servant from performing their duties.
column3: Constable Rodriguez, a dedicated public servant, was tasked with maintaining order during a local festival. However, a troublemaker named Mia, with a penchant for causing chaos, decided to intentionally obstruct Constable Rodriguez from carrying out her duties. As the constable was directing traffic to ensure the smooth flow of the event, Mia deliberately interfered by creating a barricade with unauthorized barriers, diverting the traffic into disarray.

column2: Whoever, being bound by law to render or furnish assistance to any public servant in the execution of his public duty, intentionally omits to give such assistance.
column3: John, a local resident, found himself witnessing a chaotic scene unfold one sunny afternoon. Officer Smith, a dedicated public servant, was attempting to control a rowdy crowd during a community event. every citizen is obligated to assist a public servant in carrying out their duties. In this situation, John, aware of this legal duty, intentionally chose not to lend a helping hand to Officer Smith. Despite the officer's pleas for support in managing the unruly crowd, John stood by, omitting to provide the necessary assistance as required by law.

column2: Whoever, being bound by law to render or furnish assistance to any public servant in the execution of his public duty, intentionally omits to give such assistance.
column3: Emma, a shop owner, observed a street altercation escalating between two individuals. Nearby, Constable Taylor, a local police officer, rushed to the scene to intervene and restore peace.citizens like Emma are legally obligated to assist public servants in carrying out their duties. However, in this instance, Emma, for reasons known only to her, consciously chose not to provide any assistance to Constable Taylor. Despite the officer's explicit request for help in calming the situation, Emma opted to stay on the sidelines.

column2: someone disobeys a lawful order given by a public servant, and it causes annoyance, risk of harm, or danger to others.
column3: Officer Johnson, a dedicated public servant, found himself in a challenging situation. One day, he issued a lawful order to Mr. Smith, instructing him to divert his vehicle away from a busy intersection due to ongoing road repairs. However, Mr. Smith, driven by impatience, willfully disobeyed Officer Johnson's order. As a result, traffic chaos ensued, causing annoyance and increasing the risk of harm to pedestrians and other motorists.

column2: someone disobeys a lawful order given by a public servant, and it causes annoyance, risk of harm, or danger to others.
column3: a dedicated public servant, faced a challenging situation when she issued a lawful order to Mr. Patel during a public event. The order was to refrain from flying drones in the crowded area, as it posed a risk to the safety of the gathering. Ignoring the directive, Mr. Patel continued to fly his drone, causing annoyance among the crowd and raising concerns about the potential danger it posed.

column2: anyone who threatens to harm a public servant or someone connected to that public servant to influence their official duties .
column3: Officer Sarah Thompson, a dedicated and respected police officer, found herself facing a grave situation. John Stevens, a disgruntled citizen, grew increasingly dissatisfied with a recent legal matter involving his family. Frustrated and seeking retribution, John resorted to making explicit threats against Officer Thompson and her family, explicitly mentioning harm to her spouse, Mark, to coerce her into using her official position for his benefit. John's menacing words not only placed Officer Thompson in fear for her loved ones but also aimed to manipulate her in the execution of her duties.

column2: anyone who threatens to harm a public servant or someone connected to that public servant to influence their official duties .
column3: Mayor Emma Rodriguez faced a harrowing situation that tested the resilience of her commitment to public service. A local business owner, Lisa Chambers, dissatisfied with the city's recent zoning decisions, resorted to extreme measures. Lisa, driven by frustration and anger, sent a series of menacing messages to Mayor Rodriguez, explicitly threatening harm to her teenage daughter, Emily, if the mayor didn't use her influence to change the zoning laws in Lisa's favor.

column2: anyone who threatens to harm someone to prevent them from seeking legal protection against a public servant.
column3: a local resident named John, dissatisfied with the actions of a public servant named Officer Smith, decided to file a complaint against him for alleged misconduct. Concerned about the potential consequences of such legal action, a friend of Officer Smith, named Mark, took it upon himself to intimidate John. In an attempt to prevent John from seeking legal protection against Officer Smith, Mark threatened to harm John and his family if he dared to proceed with the complaint.

column2: anyone who threatens to harm someone to prevent them from seeking legal protection against a public servant.
column3: a citizen named Sarah discovered evidence of corruption involving a public official, Mayor Anderson. Fearing the repercussions of exposing the misconduct, Sarah hesitated to report it. However, her neighbor, Emily, who happened to be a close associate of Mayor Anderson, caught wind of Sarah's concerns. In a misguided attempt to shield the mayor from legal scrutiny, Emily resorted to issuing threats against Sarah. Emily warned Sarah that harm would befall her and her property if she dared to bring the corruption allegations to light.

column2: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, or being bound by law to make a declaration upon any subject, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence.
column3: Imagine a witness in a court proceeding who has taken an oath to tell the truth. The witness is asked about an event they witnessed, but instead of providing accurate information, the witness knowingly makes a false statement. For instance, the witness claims to have seen a person at the scene of the crime when, in reality, they were not present. In this case, the act of providing false information under oath or by legal obligation constitutes giving false evidence.

column2: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, or being bound by law to make a declaration upon any subject, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence.
column3: Consider a sworn expert witness in a trial. This witness, bound by the duty to provide truthful and unbiased professional opinions, is asked to assess the safety of a product. Instead of presenting an accurate evaluation based on their expertise, the expert knowingly provides false information, asserting that the product is completely safe when, in fact, it poses significant risks. In this scenario, the act of deliberately offering inaccurate information while under oath constitutes giving false evidence.

column2: defines ""fabricating false evidence"" as causing false information to be present in a record or document with the intention that it may be used in a judicial or legal proceeding, leading to a wrong conclusion.
column3: In a property dispute, one party fabricates a fake lease agreement, claiming it grants them ownership rights. The falsified document is introduced in court to mislead the legal proceedings, aiming to secure a favorable judgment. This act of fabricating false evidence involves intentionally inserting deceptive information into the case, potentially leading to an incorrect legal conclusion.

column2: Creating public nuisance

The noise from heavy machinery and construction tools disturbs the sleep of nearby residents, affecting their peace and quiet. Despite complaints from neighbors, the construction company continues the disruptive work, creating a public nuisance by interfering with the comfort and well-being of the community.

column2: Creating public nuisance

The event quickly grows beyond the park's capacity, causing congestion and hindering the ability of other parkgoers to enjoy the space peacefully. The organizers fail to manage the crowd and address safety concerns, creating a public nuisance that disrupts the normal use of the park for everyone else in the community.

column2:
Except in the cases hereinafter excepted, culpable homicide is murder, if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or-

2ndly.-If it is done with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows to be likely to cause the death of the person to whom the harm is caused, or-

3rdly.-If it is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, or-

4thly.-If the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death, or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid.


IPC 300 in Simple Words
According to section 300 of the Indian Penal Code, culpable homicide is considered murder if the act is done with the intention of causing death or causing bodily injury likely to cause death, or if the act is so dangerous that it is likely to cause death or serious bodily injury and is done without any excuse for taking such a risk.


Exception 1.-When culpable homicide is not murder.-Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender, whilst deprived of the power of self-control by grave and sudden provocation, causes the death of the person who gave the provocation or causes the death of any other person by mistake or accident.

The above exception is subject to the following provisos:-

First.-That the provocation is not sought or voluntarily provoked by the offender as an excuse for killing or doing harm to any person.

Secondly.-That the provocation is not given by anything done in obedience to the law, or by a public servant in the lawful exercise of the powers of such public servant.

Thirdly.-That the provocation is not given by anything done in the lawful exercise of the right of private defence.

Explanation.-Whether the provocation was grave and sudden enough to prevent the offence from amounting to murder is a question of fact.


Exception 2.-Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender in the exercise in good faith of the right of private defence of person or property, exceeds the power given to him by law and causes the death of the person against whom he is exercising such right of defence without premeditation, and without any intention of doing more harm than is necessary for the purpose of such defence.

Illustration

Z attempts to horsewhip A, not in such a manner as to cause grievous hurt to A. A draws out a pistol. Z persists in the assault. A believing in good faith that he can by no other means prevent himself from being horsewhipped, shoots Z dead. A has not committed murder, but only culpable homicide.

Exception 3.-Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender, being a public servant or aiding a public servant acting for the advancement of public justice, exceeds the powers given to him by law, and causes death by doing an act which he, in good faith, believes to be lawful and necessary for the due discharge of his duty as such public servant and without ill-will towards the person whose death is caused.

Exception 4.-Culpable homicide is not murder if it is committed without premeditation in a sudden fight

Exception 3.-Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender, being a public servant or aiding a public servant acting for the advancement of public justice, exceeds the powers given to him by law, and causes death by doing an act which he, in good faith, believes to be lawful and necessary for the due discharge of his duty as such public servant and without ill-will towards the person whose death is caused.

column2:
Except in the cases hereinafter excepted, culpable homicide is murder, if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or-

2ndly.-If it is done with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows to be likely to cause the death of the person to whom the harm is caused, or-

3rdly.-If it is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, or-

4thly.-If the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death, or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid.


IPC 300 in Simple Words
According to section 300 of the Indian Penal Code, culpable homicide is considered murder if the act is done with the intention of causing death or causing bodily injury likely to cause death, or if the act is so dangerous that it is likely to cause death or serious bodily injury and is done without any excuse for taking such a risk.


Exception 1.-When culpable homicide is not murder.-Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender, whilst deprived of the power of self-control by grave and sudden provocation, causes the death of the person who gave the provocation or causes the death of any other person by mistake or accident.

The above exception is subject to the following provisos:-

First.-That the provocation is not sought or voluntarily provoked by the offender as an excuse for killing or doing harm to any person.

Secondly.-That the provocation is not given by anything done in obedience to the law, or by a public servant in the lawful exercise of the powers of such public servant.

Thirdly.-That the provocation is not given by anything done in the lawful exercise of the right of private defence.

Explanation.-Whether the provocation was grave and sudden enough to prevent the offence from amounting to murder is a question of fact.


Exception 2.-Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender in the exercise in good faith of the right of private defence of person or property, exceeds the power given to him by law and causes the death of the person against whom he is exercising such right of defence without premeditation, and without any intention of doing more harm than is necessary for the purpose of such defence.

Illustration

Z attempts to horsewhip A, not in such a manner as to cause grievous hurt to A. A draws out a pistol. Z persists in the assault. A believing in good faith that he can by no other means prevent himself from being horsewhipped, shoots Z dead. A has not committed murder, but only culpable homicide.

Exception 3.-Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender, being a public servant or aiding a public servant acting for the advancement of public justice, exceeds the powers given to him by law, and causes death by doing an act which he, in good faith, believes to be lawful and necessary for the due discharge of his duty as such public servant and without ill-will towards the person whose death is caused.

Exception 4.-Culpable homicide is not murder if it is committed without premeditation in a sudden fight

column2:
The following kinds of hurt only are designated as "grievous":
Emasculation.
Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
Privation of any member or joint.
Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint.
Permanent disfiguration of the head or face.
Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.
Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of twenty days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.
column3: John, in a violent altercation, inflicts grievous hurt by fracturing his opponent's jaw, causing severe pain and impairing the ability to eat or speak. The act results in permanent disfigurement, meeting the criteria of grievous hurt under the law

column2:
A man is said to commit “rape” if he—
penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body, not being the penis, into the vagina, the urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
manipulates any part of the body of a woman so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus or any part of body of such woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
applies his mouth to the vagina, anus, urethra of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person, under the circumstances falling under any of the following seven descriptions:
Against her will.
Without her consent.
With her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested, in fear of death or of hurt.
With her consent, when the man knows that he is not her husband and that her consent is given because she believes that he is another man to whom she is or believes herself to be lawfully married.
With her consent when, at the time of giving such consent, by reason of unsoundness of mind or intoxication or the administration by him personally or through another of any stupefying or unwholesome Substance, she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent.
With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.
When she is unable to communicate consent.
Explanations
For the purposes of this section, “vagina” shall also include labia majora.
Consent means an unequivocal voluntary agreement when the woman by words, gestures or any form of verbal or non-verbal communication, communicates willingness to participate in the specific sexual act;

Provided that a woman who does not physically resist to the act of penetration shall not by the reason only of that fact, be regarded as consenting to the sexual activity.
Exceptions
A medical procedure or intervention shall not constitute rape.
Sexual intercourse or sexual acts by a man with his own wife, the wife not being under fifteen years of age, is not rape.

She tried to contact the accused after this but he was nowhere to be found. She filed a complaint against him.
